{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} An '''Accession Day''' is usually the anniversary of the date on which a monarch or executive takes office. The earliest records of accession celebrations date from the reign of Queen [[Elizabeth I of England]], and the custom is now observed in many nations.
Accession Day in India's [[Jammu and Kashmir]] commemorates the day in 1947 when the area joined the [[Dominion of India]].
==Belgium== In Belgium there are local celebrations of the reigning monarch's accession, but the anniversary of the accession of the first King of modern Belgium, [[Leopold I of Belgium|Leopold I]], on 21 July 1831, is celebrated as a full national holiday, known as "Belgian National Day".<ref>See page 9 of [http://www.belgium.be/en/binaries/belgium_at_a_glance_tcm115-36271.pdf this] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130421055822/http://www.belgium.be/en/binaries/belgium_at_a_glance_tcm115-36271.pdf |date=21 April 2013 }} document from the Belgian Federal Government website.</ref>
==Indian subcontinent== [[Accession Day (Jammu and Kashmir)|Accession Day]] is a state holiday in India's northernmost state, [[Jammu and Kashmir]], commemorating 26 October 1947, when [[Maharaja Hari Singh]] signed off the [[Instrument of Accession (Jammu and Kashmir)|Instrument of Accession]], in which [[Kashmir and Jammu (princely state)|Jammu and Kashmir]] joined the [[Dominion of India]]. This was part of the series of events in 1947 by which rule the Indian Empire was converted into the two new Dominions of India and Pakistan, the latter having two territories separated by the whole of northern India. As a Hindu ruler of a state with both Hindu and Muslim subjects, the Maharaja's decision was crucial.
Festivities of the day include holding rallies, lighting [[firecrackers]], singing [[National anthem of India|India's national anthem]], and raising the [[flag of India]].<ref name="Greater Kashmir">{{cite web|url=http://www.greaterkashmir.com/news/2010/Oct/28/accession-day-is-our-national-day-jmu-bar-33.asp |title=Accession day is our national day: Jammu BAR |publisher=[[Greater Kashmir]] |accessdate=31 December 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101028221720/http://www.greaterkashmir.com/news/2010/Oct/28/accession-day-is-our-national-day-jmu-bar-33.asp |archivedate=28 October 2010 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name = "Sify - Accession Day">{{cite web| url = http://sify.com/news/jammu-all-set-to-celebrate-accession-day-news-national-kkzsuicghgb.html|title=Jammu all set to celebrate Accession Day|publisher=[[Sify]]|accessdate =31 December 2007}}</ref><ref name="Vijay Kumar - Accession Day">{{cite web|url=http://www.groundreport.com/World/J-K-Accession-day-celebrations-in-J-K_7/2930440 |title=J&K Accession Day celebrations in Jammu & Kashmir |publisher=[[GroundReport]] |accessdate=31 December 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101029163930/http://www.groundreport.com/World/J-K-Accession-day-celebrations-in-J-K_7/2930440 |archivedate=29 October 2010 |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Netherlands== {{main|Koningsdag}} ''Koninginnedag'' (Queen's Day) was, during the reign of Queen [[Beatrix of the Netherlands|Beatrix]], celebrated on 30 April, the date of her accession in 1980 upon the abdication of her mother, Queen Juliana, whose birthday fell on 30 April). Beatrix abdicated on Koninginnedag 2013 which, led to the accession of King [[Willem-Alexander of the Netherlands|Willem-Alexander]]. As a result, the holiday became known as Koningsdag (King's Day) from 2014 and the celebration was moved three days ahead to 27 April, to instead mark the birthday of Willem-Alexander.
==United Arab Emirates== The [[United Arab Emirates]] is unusual in celebrating the accession of its President, although the President is elected from amongst the seven hereditary [[Emir]]s (ruling Princes) of the constituent states of the UAE, and is therefore also a hereditary and monarchical leader. Accession Day is a national holiday in the UAE.<ref>Details of the celebration on [http://aglobalworld.com/holidays-around-the-world/uae-hh-sheikh-zayed-accession/ 6 August].</ref>
== United Kingdom == <!--Linked from [[Elizabeth II]]-->
The custom of marking this day was inaugurated during the reign of [[Elizabeth I of England|Queen Elizabeth I]] of England. Her accession day was celebrated in England and Wales during her reign and also, according to the 19th-century historian [[Thomas Lathbury]], during the reigns of her successors.<ref>"According to Lathbury, the 17th day of November, the day of the Queen's accession, was observed even after Elizabeth's death as a day of thanksgiving to Almighty God for the gracious deliverance wrought out for the Church by her instrumentality." (Evan Daniel, ''The Prayer-Book; its history, language and contents''; 26th ed. Redhill: Wells Gardner (1948), p. 535.)</ref> A "Form of Prayer and Thanksgiving" to be used in churches on the anniversary of the queen's accession was published in 1576 and used until 1602.
In 1568, the tenth anniversary of Queen Elizabeth's accession was marked with the ringing of bells and 17 November became known as "Queen Elizabeth's Day" or "[[Queene's Day]]".<ref name ="Chambers">''Chambers Book of Days'', Edinburgh: Chambers, 2004 ({{ISBN|0-550-10083-0}}) p.553 ff.</ref> As her reign progressed, it was celebrated with increased fervour and, long after her death, it continued to be observed as a day of Protestant rejoicing and expression of anti-Catholic feeling. The observances included triumphal parades and processions, sermons against populism and the burning of the Pope in effigy.<ref name ="Chambers" /> After the [[Great Fire of London]] (1666), "these rejoicings were converted into a satirical [[saturnalia]] of the most turbulent kind"; the greatest excesses occurred in the years 1679–81 when wealthy members of political clubs paid for processions and bonfires to arouse the populace to political fervour.<ref name ="Chambers" /> The inhabitants of [[Berry Pomeroy]] in south [[Devon]] reinstated the tradition of Queene's Day in 2005 with a special church service and bonfire.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/InfoWeb?p_product=UKNB&p_theme=aggregated5&p_action=doc&p_docid=1156EAAD5DD84A10&p_docnum=10&p_queryname=2 |title=Queene's day revival continues |work=Western Morning News |location=Plymouth, Devon |date=13 November 2006 |accessdate=23 June 2012}} {{subscription required}}</ref>
On the accession of [[James VI and I|King James I of England]], a form of prayer and thanksgiving was issued for use in all churches "upon his entry to this kingdom".<ref>Daniel ''Prayer-Book'', p. 535.</ref> In 1625, a new service was issued which was sanctioned by [[Convocation]] in 1640 but set aside by Parliament at the [[Restoration (1660)|Restoration]] when certain parts of it were included in the special service for 29 May. When [[James II of England|King James II]] acceded the throne, he ordered the preparation of a special form of prayer and thanksgiving for the anniversary of his accession day and a revised version of the old service was prepared and set forth by authority in 1685. The form of words "the day on which His Majesty began his happy reign" was first used in this service and has been retained ever since. After falling out of use during the reigns of [[William III of England|William III]] and [[Mary II of England|Mary II]], the service was revised and used again during the reign of [[Anne, Queen of Great Britain|Queen Anne]].<ref>Daniel ''Prayer-Book'', p. 536.</ref> King [[George V]]'s accession day (reigned 1910–36) was 6 May.<ref>''Hoe & Co's Travellers' Diary for 1927''. [[Chennai|Madras]]: Hoe & Co, p. 11.</ref>
The present monarch, [[Elizabeth II]]'s accession day is 6 February and is observed in the United Kingdom by the flying of specific flags and various [[official function]]s. In London, a [[21-gun salute#United Kingdom|Royal Salute]] is fired by the guns of the [[King's Troop, Royal Horse Artillery]] in [[Green Park]] and by the [[Honourable Artillery Company]] at the [[Tower of London]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royal.gov.uk/RoyalEventsandCeremonies/GunSalutes/Gunsalutes.aspx |title=Gun Salutes |publisher=The official website of the British Monarchy |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150317070617/http://www.royal.gov.uk/RoyalEventsandCeremonies/GunSalutes/Gunsalutes.aspx |archivedate=17 March 2015 |df=dmy }}</ref> Salutes are also fired at [[Woolwich]], [[Colchester]], [[Edinburgh Castle]], [[Stirling Castle]], [[Cardiff]], [[Belfast]], [[York]], [[Portsmouth]], [[Plymouth]] and [[Dover]] Castle.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.colchester.gov.uk/news_det.asp?art_id=8141&sec_id=27 |title=Honour of Royal Salute switches to Colchester town centre |publisher=Colchester Borough Council}}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
Special services are required by [[Canon law|canon]] in all cathedrals, churches, and chapels of the [[Church of England]]. The [[Book of Common Prayer]] provides options for a stand-alone Accession Day service, or for special [[Proper (liturgy)|proper]]s by which any or all of the services of Matins, Evensong and Holy Communion may be altered for the day.<ref>All these options are available on-line at [http://www.churchofengland.org/prayer-worship/worship/book-of-common-prayer/accession-services.aspx here].</ref> The Church's more recent prayer book [[Common Worship]] does not provide a full form of service, but refers the user to the Book of Common Prayer; it does, however, provide propers for the Eucharist on 6 February.<ref>See "Common Worship – Festivals", Church House Publishing, 2008, page 367, which may be viewed on-line [http://www.churchofengland.org/media/41176/festivalscommonofsaints.pdf here].</ref> Although not a legal requirement, special services are also held in some churches of other denominations.
== Vatican City == The Vatican counts the ''Anniversario dell'Elezione del Santo Padre'', or the anniversary of the [[Papal conclave|election]] of the reigning pontiff, among its statutory public holidays. Since 2014, the city-state has observed this holiday on March 13, the anniversary of [[Pope Francis]]' election in 2013.

'''Adia Harvey Wingfield''' is a Professor of Sociology at [[Washington University in St. Louis]] and President of [[Sociologists for Women in Society]].
== Biography == Adia Harvey Wingfield is Professor of Sociology and a Faculty Fellow in the Office of the [[Provost (education)|Provost]] at Washington University in St. Louis,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://provost.wustl.edu/people/adia-harvey-wingfield/|title=Adia Harvey Wingfield - Office of the Provost|work=Office of the Provost|access-date=2018-09-10|language=en-US}}</ref> where her research interests are in the persistence of [[Intersectionality|intersectional]] racial and gender inequalities in professional occupations,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.socialworkhelper.com/author/adia-harvey-wingfield/|title=Adia Harvey Wingfield|website=www.socialworkhelper.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-09}}</ref> in particular the challenges facing black men in workplaces where they are in the minority.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sociology.fas.harvard.edu/event/adia-wingfield-professional-work-%E2%80%9Cpost-racial%E2%80%9D-era-black-health-care-workers-new|title=Adia Wingfield: Professional Work in a "Post-Racial" Era: Black Health Care Workers in the New Economy|website=sociology.fas.harvard.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-09-10}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://pages.wustl.edu/wingfield|title=Adia Harvey Wingfield {{!}} Department of Sociology|website=pages.wustl.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-09-09}}</ref>
Wingfield obtained her Ph.D. in Sociology from [[Johns Hopkins University]],<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://sociology.wustl.edu/people/adia-harvey-wingfield|title=Adia Harvey Wingfield {{!}} Department of Sociology|website=sociology.wustl.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-09-09}}</ref> from which she also graduated with a Masters in sociology.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Hawkins|first=B. Denise|date=2013|title=Looking Up: Dr. Adia Harvey Wingfield Follows Examples of Her Parents; Explores Race, Class and Gender Issues.|url=|journal=Diverse Issues in Higher Education|volume=29|issue=24|pages=19|via=}}</ref> She attended Spelman College as an undergraduate, studying English.<ref name=":2" />
She is the author of several books, including ''No More Invisible Man: Race and Gender in Men’s Work'', and articles in peer-reviewed journals including ''[[Social Problems]]'', ''[[Gender & Society]]'', and ''[[Ethnic and Racial Studies]]''. She has lectured internationally on her research.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://socwomen.org/about/current-officers-and-chairs/|title=Current Officers and Chairs|date=2017-11-06|work=Sociologists for Women in Society|access-date=2018-09-09|language=en-US}}</ref>
She is currently President of Sociologists for Women in Society, a national organisation that encourages feminist research and teaching in sociology.<ref name=":0" />
In 2018 Wingfield received the Public Understanding of Sociology award from the [[American Sociological Association]], which recognises exemplary contributions to the advancement of the understanding of sociology and sociological research among the general public. Her book ''No More Invisible Man'' received the Distinguished Book Award from the ASA Race, Gender, and Class Section.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.asanet.org/news-events/asa-awards/2018-asa-award-recipients#wingfield|title=2018 ASA Award Recipients|date=2018-02-15|work=American Sociological Association|access-date=2018-09-10|language=en}}</ref>
== Selected publications == Wingfield's 2008 book ''Doing Business with Beauty: Black Women, Hair Salons, and the Racial Enclave Economy'' examines how working-class black women use entrepreneurship as a route to upward mobility, in particular establishing business models that center explicitly on black women's unique needs. Her 2010 article "Are Some Emotions Marked ‘Whites Only?’ Racialized Feeling Rules in Professional Workplaces" in the journal ''Social Problems'' describes how black professionals have to manage their emotions in workplaces that are predominantly white. ''No More Invisible Man: Race and Gender in Men’s Work'', published in 2013 examines the unique experiences of black men when employed in white male-dominated professional jobs, for example as lawyers, doctors, engineers, or bankers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://scholars.org/scholar/adia-wingfield|title=wingfield.adia {{!}} Scholars Strategy Network|website=scholars.org|language=en|access-date=2018-09-09}}</ref>
Wingfield is a contributing writer for ''[[The Atlantic]], [[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]],'' and ''[[Inside Higher Ed]]''.<ref name=":1" />
== Personal life == Wingfield's father, William B. Harvey, [[Doctor of Education]], was also an academic, and her mother was a [[K–12|K-12]] educator.<ref name=":2" />

'''Allow Natural Death''' ('''AND''') is a medical term defining the use of life-extending measures such as [[cardiopulmonary resuscitation]] (CPR). These orders emphasize patient comfort and [[pain management]] instead of life extension.<ref name=Schlairet>{{cite journal|last=Schlairet|first=Maura C|title=Allow-Natural-Death (AND) Orders: Legal, Ethical, And Practical Considerations|journal=HEC Forum}}</ref> Currently, American medical communities utilize “[[do not resuscitate]],” (DNR) orders to define patients’ medical wishes. Those who propose to replace DNR with AND posit that DNR orders are ambiguous and require complex understanding between several parties, while AND orders are clearer.<ref name=Schlairet /><ref name=Venneman>{{cite journal|last=Venneman|first=S.S.|title='Allow Natural Death' Versus 'Do Not Resuscitate': Three Words That Can Change A Life|journal=Journal of Medical Ethics|doi=10.1136/jme.2006.018317|volume=34|year=2008|pages=2–6}}</ref>
DNR orders range from solely prohibiting the use of resuscitation to prohibiting any action seen as life extending. Because there are many parties involved in a patient’s end of life care - significant others, family, personal doctors, specialists and nurses - DNR orders are not always completely clear, leaving open possible violation of the patient’s wishes.<ref name=Schlairet /> “DNR orders may lead to conflict, unnecessary suffering, and inappropriate care at the EOL [end of life.]” Those who propose to replace DNR orders with AND orders posit that AND are less ambiguous, clearly instructing medical personnel to not use any artificial, life extending measures. This would be especially helpful in regards to emergency care, when medical personnel who are unfamiliar with the patient must decide what medical practices should be used. Furthermore, proponents of AND claim that because it contains “death” in the title it is more clear to the patient and family exactly what the patient is agreeing to.
Critics of AND claim it is simply the replacement of one ambiguous term with another. Just as DNR particulars vary so too would AND particulars vary. Thus, the change would be ineffective.<ref name=Chen>{{cite journal|last=Chen|first=Y-Y|title='Allow Natural Death' Is Not Equivalent To 'Do Not Resuscitate': A Response|journal=Journal of Medical Ethics|doi=10.1136/jme.2008.024570|volume=34|year=2008|pages=887–888}}</ref>

'''Amarna Letter EA5''' is a [[diplomatic correspondence|correspondence]] between [[Kadashman-Enlil I|Kadašman-Enlil I]] and [[Amenhotep III]].
The letter exists as two artifacts, one at the [[British Museum]] (BM29787) and one in the [[Cairo Museum]] (C12195).<ref name="W.L.Moran (edited and translated)">{{cite book |url=https://roberthaug.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/amarna-letters.pdf|author=W.L.Moran (edited and translated)|title=The Amarna Letters|publisher=published by the Johns Hopkins University Press - Baltimore, London|accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref><ref>P. Sundberg - [https://www.usc.edu/dept/LAS/wsrp/educational_site/ancient_texts/elamarna.shtml El-Amarna Tablets] ''West Semitic Research Project'' (University of Southern California) [Retrieved 2015-07-05]</ref>
The letter is part of a series of correspondences from [[Babylonia]] to Egypt, which run from EA2 to EA4 and EA6 to EA14. EA1 and EA5 are from [[Egypt]] to Babylonia.<ref name="W.L.Moran (edited and translated)"/><ref>W.L.Moran (edited and translated) - [https://canvas.brown.edu/courses/949665/files/43710429/download The Amarna Letters (p.xvi)] published by the Johns Hopkins University Press - Baltimore, London (Brown University) [Retrieved 2015-07-09]</ref>
The inscription translated reads:<ref name="W.L.Moran (edited and translated)"/> ---- ---- {{quote|''Thus Nibmuareya Great King the king of Egypt. Say to Kadašman-Enlil, the king of Karaduniyaš my brother for me all goes well For you may all go well For your household your wives your sons your magnates your troops your horses your chariots and in your countries may all go well. For me all goes well my household my wives my sons my magnates my many troops my horses my chariots and in my countries all goes very very well.''}}
{{quote|I have just heard you built some new quarters I am sending herewith some for your house Indeed I shall be preparing everything possible before the arrival of the messenger who is bringing your daughter When your messenger returns I will send them to you I herewith send to you in the charge of Šutti a greeting gift of things for the new house 1 bed of ebony overlaid with ivory and gold 3 beds of ebony overlaid with gold 1 uruššu of ebony overlaid with gold 1 large chair of ebony overlaid with gold 5 chairs of ebony overlaid with gold 4 chairs of ebony overlaid with gold These things the weight of all the gold 7 minas 9 shekels of gold The weight of the silver 1 mina 8 and a half shekels of silver In addition 10 footrests of ebony ... of ebony overlaid with gold ... footrests of ivory overlaid with gold ... of gold Total ... minas 10 and 7 shekels of gold}} ---- ----
==See also== *[[Chronology of the ancient Near East#Egypt|Chronology of the ancient Near East]] *Amarna letters: [[Amarna letter EA 1|EA 1]], [[Amarna letter EA 2|EA 2]], [[Amarna letter EA 3|EA 3]], [[Amarna letter EA 4|EA 4]], [[Amarna letter EA 6|EA 6]], [[Amarna letter EA 7|EA 7]], [[Amarna letter EA 8|EA 8]], [[Amarna letter EA 9|EA 9]], [[Amarna letter EA 10|EA 10]], [[Amarna letter EA 11|EA 11]]
==External links== *[https://www.britishmuseum.org/collectionimages/AN00331/AN00331061_001_l.jpg Photo EA 5, Obverse, (British Museum piece: BM 29787)] *[https://www.britishmuseum.org/collectionimages/AN00331/AN00331066_001_l.jpg Photo EA 5, Reverse, (British Museum piece: BM 29787)] (note: line 17 from Obverse extends across the entire Reverse (upside down cuneiform))

{{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Andrzej Szczypiorski | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1924|2|3|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Warsaw]], [[Poland]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2000|5|16|1928|2|3|df=y}} | death_place = [[Warsaw]], [[Poland]] | occupation = [[novelist]], [[politician]], [[diplomat]] | nationality = [[Poland|Polish]] | genre = [[novel]], [[short story]] | movement = | notableworks = A Mass for Arras (pl.: Msza za miasto Arras) | influences = | influenced = | signature = }} [[File:Andrzej_Szczypiorski_grave.JPG|thumb|250px]] '''Andrzej Szczypiorski''' ({{IPA-pl|ˈandʐeɪ̯ ʂt͡ʂɨˈpʲɔrski}}, {{Audio|Pl-Andrzej Szczypiorski.ogg|help=no|listen}}; 3 February 1928 – 16 May 2000) was a [[Poles|Polish]] [[novelist]] and [[politician]]. He served as a member of the Polish legislature, and was a [[Solidarity (Polish trade union)|Solidarity]] activist interned during the [[Martial law in Poland|military crackdown of 1981]]. He was a secret police agent in the 1950s.<ref name="newsweek">{{cite web | url=http://polska.newsweek.pl/tajemnica-szczypiorskiego,14376,1,1.html | title=Tajemnica Szczypiorskiego (Szczypiorski's Secret) | publisher=''Newsweek.pl'' Polska | date=May 7, 2006 | accessdate=March 28, 2013}}</ref>
==Life== He was son of [[Adam Szczypiorski]], a political activist, historian and mathematician, and Jadwiga née Epsztajn. Szczypiorski had a sister Wiesława (1924-1945). He spent his childhood in [[Warsaw]].
During [[World War II]] Szczypiorski studied at [[Education in Poland during World War II|an underground university]] called the "flying university" due to the regular changing of its location for safety. He was a partisan of the Polish [[Armia Ludowa|People’s Army]], and a participant of the [[Warsaw Uprising]]. After the Uprising he was arrested and condemned to imprisonment at the [[Sachsenhausen concentration camp]], where he survived until 1945.
In 1946-1947 he studied political science in the Warsaw Consular Diplomatic Academy. In 1948-1956, Szczypiorski worked as an editor in the Katowice Silesian Theater. During this period, in 1952, he made his literary debut in the magazine "Życie Literackie" using the pseudonym 'Maurice S. Andrews' and was inducted into the [[Polish Writers' Union]]. He won the [[Austrian State Prize for European Literature]] in 1988.<ref name="1988prize">{{cite web |url=http://www.oesterreich-bibliotheken.at/preistraegerinnen.php?preis=preise_euliteratur |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120529161211/http://www.oesterreich-bibliotheken.at/preistraegerinnen.php?preis=preise_euliteratur |dead-url=yes |archive-date=29 May 2012 |title=Österreichische StaatspreisträgerInnen für Europäische Literatur |publisher=Oesterreich-Bibliotheken im Ausland |language=German |accessdate=30 April 2013 }}</ref>
In 1956-1958, he was selected to serve in the Polish Embassy to [[Denmark]], after which he returned to work as an editor on the radio and for publications. He later served as a member of the Polish legislature. He was also a [[UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador]]. Prior to his death, Szczypiorski converted to [[Calvinism]], and is buried in the [[Protestant Reformed Cemetery in Warsaw]].
After his death it became known that Szczypiorski was a collaborator of the [[Ministry of Public Security (Poland)|Polish communist secret police]] in the years of [[Stalinism in Poland]].<ref name="newsweek" />
== Awards == * 1972 Polish [[International PEN|PEN-Club]] Prize * 1988 [[Austrian State Prize for European Literature]] * 1989 [[Nelly Sachs Prize]] * 1994 [[Herder Prize]]

{{italic title}} [[Image:Gillray-Cave.jpg|thumb|[[James Gillray]], "A Peep Into the Cave of Jacobinism" (1798). Published in the ''Anti-Jacobin Review''.]] '''''The Anti-Jacobin Review and Magazine, or, Monthly Political and Literary Censor''''' (1798 to 1821), a conservative British political periodical, was founded by [[John Gifford]] [pseud. of John Richards Green] (1758–1818) after the demise of [[William Gifford]]'s ''[[Anti-Jacobin|The Anti-Jacobin, or, Weekly Examiner]]'' (1797–1798). Gifford and Robert Bisset were the chief writers, and the political philosopher [[James Mill]] wrote reviews. Described as "often scurrilous" and "ultra-[[Tory]]," <ref>John Strachan, “[http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/10669 Gifford, William (1756–1826)],” ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Ed. H. C. G. Matthew and Brian Harrison (Oxford: OUP, 2004. Online ed. Ed. Lawrence Goldman. May 2006. 7 May 2007).</ref> the journal contained essays, reviews, and satirical engravings, notably by [[James Gillray]]. It grew out of the political ferment of the period and was a vocal element of the British Anti-[[Jacobin (politics)|Jacobin]] backlash against the ideals of the [[French Revolution]].
The first edition was published on 1 August 1798 and was advertised in ''[[The Times]]'' as "containing Original Criticism; a Review of the Reviewers; Miscellaneous Matter in Prose and Verse, Lists of Marriages, Births, Deaths and Promotions; and a Summary of Foreign and Domestic Politics."<ref name="Times-1798-Jul-20">{{cite newspaper The Times|articlename=New Review and Magazine|section=Classified Advertising|date=20 July 1798|page_number=2|issue=4235|accessdate=2016-11-13}}</ref>
Contributors included Robert Bisset (1758/9–1805), [[John Bowles (author)|John Bowles]] (1751–1819), Arthur Cayley (1776–1848), [[George Gleig]], Samuel Henshall (1764/5–1807), [[James Hurdis]], [[John Oxlee]] (1779–1854), Richard Penn (1733/4–1811), [[Richard Polwhele]], [[John Skinner (bishop)|John Skinner]] (1744–1816), William Stevens (1732–1807), and [[John Whitaker (historian)|John Whitaker]] (1735–1808), though as items were frequently published anonymously attributions are often unclear.
It denounced reformers, especially the Evangelicals, and greatly angered them, as [[William Wilberforce]], a leader of the anti-slavery movement, made clear in 1800: :It is a most mischievous publication, which, by dint of assuming a tone of the highest loyalty and attachment to our establishment in church and state, secures a prejudice in its favour, and has declared war against what I think the most respectable and most useful of all orders of men--the serious clergy of the Church of England. . . . Its opposition to the evangelical clergy is carried on in so venomous a way, and with so much impudence, and so little regard to truth, that the mischief it does is very great indeed. It accuses them in the plainest terms, and sometimes by name, as being disaffected both to church and state.<ref>Quoted in Ford K. Brown, ''Fathers of the Victorians: The Age of Wilberforce'' (1961) p 187.</ref>

{{Infobox journal | cover = ArchivesofAsianArtvol57.jpg | discipline = [[Art]] | abbreviation = Arch. Asian Art | formernames = Archives of the Chinese Art Society of America | publisher = [[University of Hawaii Press]] on behalf of the [[Asia Society]] | country = United States | frequency = Annual | history = 1945–present | website = http://www.uhpress.hawaii.edu/journals/asianart/ | link1 = http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/archives_of_asian_art/ | link1-name = Online access at [[Project MUSE]] | ISSN = 0066-6637 | JSTOR = 00666637 }} '''''Archives of Asian Art''''' is an annual [[academic journal]] covering [[the arts]] of South, Southeast, Central, and East Asia. Each issue contains articles by [[scholar]]s of [[art]] and a selection of outstanding works of Asian art acquired by North American [[art museum|museums]] during the previous year.
The journal was established in 1945 as the ''Archives of the Chinese Art Society of America''. It obtained its current title with volume 20 in 1966. The journal is owned by the [[Asia Society]], which in 2007 changed its publisher from [[Brepols]] to the [[University of Hawaii Press]].
Volumes 1–55 (1945–2005) are available on [[JSTOR]]; recent volumes are available on [[Project MUSE]].
